head.supplied: [Bombala, 12 January 1887] ¶ ¶ [...] ¶ ¶ While upon this subject I would with all deference ask you in any instance of that kind, always kindly to give me the name of any plant according to Baron vo...

div.p: MRS 202/12 special bundle, collector, Archives of the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Ultimo, New South Wales.

While upon this subject I would with all deference ask you in any instance of that kind, always kindly to give me the name of any plant according to Baron von Müllers: "Census," so as to avoid mistakes as much as possible.

Re the specimens sent from Colombo I wish to say that what I sent under the vernacular of "Yellow Box" the Baron has determined to be Eucalyptus melliodora (Cunningham) and what I sent under the name of "Rough Stringy Bark" he has named: Eucalyptus haemastoma (Smith) The last does not agree with the Euc. haemastoma farther north, neither in leaves, bark of gum, though I sent the Baron the complete series of specimens, branchlets with bud, flower and fruit in all advancing stages. What am I to do? I think it will be best to make up a series of specimens for you of such of the Eucalypts about which there is the least doubt; a series of Herbarium Specimens I mean whatever time I can get the specimens complete: in bud flower and fruit. It might take some time, but it will be not very difficult, as I keep notes about all I have sent you, and may eventually do away with some of the confusion existing at present.

My engagement with the Baron will end soon (or rather it is at an end now) for the present, therefore I shall be able to devote more time to your wants, though for the next few weeks I intend to go over the border into Victoria to examine a few mountains Baron von Müller would much like to have examined, in hopes to make additions to the Flora of Victoria.

To day I dispatch a bag containing leaves and bark of what is here called the "Red Gum".
MS annotation by Maiden: ' E. Gunnii var: see [...] 187/87'. Next week I shall no doubt be able to send you the proper name as determined by the Baron, and will look out for flowering and fruiting specimens for you at once.
